ASHEVILLE — Democrats are tired of a Republican-controlled state legislature they say has decimated education on all levels and not stood up for the everyday resident, and they're optimistic the slate of 2016 candidates can bring change to Raleigh.

"People are seeing a path forward," Holly Jones, Buncombe County commissioner who is running for lieutenant governor, said Saturday night at the party's annual Western Gala. "There's a lot of energy, a lot of enthusiasm."

Jones and numerous other statewide Democratic candidates and supporters in a capacity crowd at the gala at the Renaissance Hotel downtown described the party's stance heading into 2016 as "getting North Carolina back on track," on key issues like funding for public education, expanding Medicaid and restoring local municipality control. Jennifer Granholm, former two-term governor of Michigan who teaches at the University of California-Berkeley, delivered a rousing call to action.

"The overreach into local government is just incomprehensible," Jones said when asked about a series of recent General Assembly bills that have limited local authority on issues ranging from the appearance of homes to this month's court decision upholding the transfer of Asheville's water system to the Metropolitan Sewerage District.
Jones said she would work hard to repeal some of those laws and described a "disconnect" between state and local government that is losing touch with residents.

Attorney General Roy Cooper, who this week formally announced a long-expected challenge to Republican Gov. Pat McCrory, said the legislature needs to pass laws that allow local governments to do what they see fit.

"The legislature is taking authority away from local governments and doing many of the same things that they complain about Washington doing to the states," Cooper said in an interview before the gala.
"I believe the government closest to the people governs the best," Cooper said.
Cooper, 58, is from Nash County and is expected to be challenged in the Democratic primary by Ken Spaulding, a Durham lawyer.

Cooper's campaign centers on serving the everyday resident, which he maintains McCrory's agenda has moved away from. "We have a governor and a legislature that won't find a way to keep good teachers, but they find a way to pass corporate tax giveaways," Cooper said.
The administration isn't "putting money in the pocket of the middle class," but taking it out by expanding the sales tax and making everyday needs like car repairs more expensive, he said.
"North Carolina should work for everyone and not just the few," he said.

He said the future of the state's economy is in a strong small business sector. He recognized WNC's importance to the state, particularly in tourism, and said infrastructure repairs are key to good-paying jobs.

Granholm, after opening with a rhyming performance poem describing the similarities of Michigan and North Carolina that included the line, "to get out of political Purgatory, you've got to replace Governor McCrory," called on Democrats to fight against the loss of middle class jobs and to stand up for other shared values. "We value workers and work. That's who we are," Granholm said.

She described herself as "obsessed" with the question of how to create good jobs in America in a global economy. "We want Roy, when he's elected, to be kept up at night over how to create good-paying jobs in North Carolina for your citizens, right?" Democrats have created 2.1 million jobs a year since 1961; Republicans 1.1 million, she said. Of the 10 poorest states, nine are Republican states. "The facts are on our side," she said, to applause.

Sen. Brian Turner, D-Buncombe, said he's been encouraged by Cooper's campaign speeches so far, particularly Cooper's stance on public education. Turner highlighted a sense of frustration over "the confusion and the inability of the (UNC) Board of Governors to actually function" and said the board's credibility has been damaged.
"They rode Tom Ross out on a rail and now they're wondering why they're having a problem finding someone to replace him," Turner said.
On Friday, the board in a widely derided move recessed after hours behind closed doors discussing the search for Ross' successor as president of the UNC system, but made no announcement.

Cooper's pledge to expand Medicaid is key, Turner said. "McCrory has continued to say, 'I'm going to think about it' and, unfortunately, people who need that health care, they don't have the luxury of Gov. McCrory's time," Turner said.
Senate candidate Deborah Ross said economic security, access to quality education and protecting equal opportunity are top issues for her campaign.
"I think that people want change and that there's a big mess in Washington, and our elected leaders in Washington are not putting people first," said Ross, who served in the state House from 2003-13.
Asked for her take on local control, Ross said, "I think that there's been governmental overreach with respect to municipalities coming from Raleigh."
Democrat leaders said the party has the support of the working class, as well as young people.

"The Republican Party ideas and principles — that's not our generation," said Justin Conley, president of the Young Democrats of North Carolina. Young people think the administration's leaders have demonstrated through policy that they don't value the service of educators and in fact have increased tuition. "It's time to move on," he said.

"We just have to think about everyone — not just the people who are wealthy and well-connected," said Rhonda Cole Schandevel, a Haywood County School Board member who's running for the House seat held by Rep. Michele Presnell, R-Yancey.
"We have got to stop the madness that's going on with the General Assembly cutting the funds that support our public education system," she said.
WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats vowed Thursday to push for stronger background check laws for gun purchases in the wake of last week's mass shooting at an Oregon community college.

Nine people were killed at Umpqua Community College in Roseburg, Ore., on Oct. 1 by a gunman who killed himself after being wounded by police. The shooting has prompted calls for action by the victims' families and friends, but the Republican majority in Congress has so far opposed any new restrictions on gun buyers.

Acknowledging that it's not yet possible to pass stricter gun laws, Democrats said they are appealing to Americans to pressure lawmakers to act in the months ahead. Previous efforts have failed in the aftermath of other mass shootings.
"We're here to start a national movement," said Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Va., who was governor when a gunman killed 32 people in a rampage at Virginia Tech in 2007.

Kaine joined about 30 other Democratic senators at a news conferences on the Capitol steps to outline a package of tougher gun laws. Supporters included Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for president.

The issue underscores a key difference between Democratic and Republican candidates. While Sanders and fellow Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton have called for stricter background check laws, Republican presidential candidates have largely opposed them.
GOP candidate Ben Carson made headlines earlier this week when he said, "I never saw a body with bullet holes that was more devastating than taking the right to arm ourselves away."
Republican front-runner Donald Trump said that "people are going to slip through the cracks" of the mental health system, regardless of background check laws.

The Democratic senators' first proposal calls for closing a loophole that allows people to buy guns online and at gun shows without undergoing the background checks that are required at big retail stores and small gun shops.

A second change would ensure that people are not allowed to buy guns without a completed background check. In some states, gun buyers can take their firearms home from the store while waiting for a background check to be finished.

People convicted of domestic abuse — whether against a spouse or someone they are dating — would be banned from buying guns. Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., has already introduced a bill that would expand the definition of a domestic abuser to include stalkers and abusers who target their dating partners.

The Democrats also proposed making it a federal crime to be a "straw buyer" who purchases a gun for someone who is not legally allowed to have a firearm. The senators also want to strengthen penalties for illegal gun trafficking across state lines.

"The victims and their families deserve better than a Congress that shrugs its shoulders and waits for the next tragedy," said Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., as he spoke about the Umpqua Community College shooting. "They deserve action."
It may be remembered as the moment when Hillary Clinton’s grip on the Democratic nomination became firm.

Vice President Biden’s decision not to challenge her front-runner status clears the way for Clinton to shore up support from 2016 primary voters who viewed him as a better alternative — but who are unlikely to support Sen. Bernie Sanders, the self-described democratic socialist from Vermont.

In a statement following Biden's announcement, the Democratic front-runner credited Biden with helping to save the auto industry and pulling the economy back from the brink of depression: "It’s a record to be proud of, defend, and build on. And I am confident that history isn’t finished with Joe Biden."
Clinton called Biden a "good man and a great vice president."
"And if I know Joe, he will always be on the front-lines, always fighting for all of us," she said.
In his speech, Biden did not endorse Clinton, and even appeared to take a swipe over a comment she made at last week's Democratic debate about Republicans being her enemy.
It’s a slight that does not help her, yet it’s also unlikely to stop Biden’s would-be voters from lining up behind Clinton, said Julian Zelizer, a U.S. politics expert at Princeton University.

"She’s been waiting for the all-systems go. Without Biden running she can now concentrate all her firepower on co-opting Bernie Sanders’ message and focusing voter attention on the fact that she’s the one who can defeat the Republican nominee,’’ Zelizer said.

In the immediate aftermath of Biden’s announcement, Clinton supporters, led by some of the top female lawmakers in Congress, sent out expressions of admiration for the vice president. Even some of Clinton’s Republican challengers quipped that the move is decisive in clearing her path for the Democratic nomination. Republican Ben Carson said, "It pretty much guarantees Hillary is who we will run against."
Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus described Biden’s decision not to enter the race as "a major blow for Democrats.’’
Biden "was the most formidable general election candidate the Democrat Party could have fielded, and his decision not to challenge Hillary Clinton greatly improves our chances,’’ he said.
Meanwhile, top Democrats focused their reactions on saluting Biden's career.
House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi took to Twitter to say "Biden is an all-American patriot and a middle-class warrior!’’

California Sen. Barbara Boxer last week suggested Biden should not challenge Clinton following the former secretary of State’s widely praised debate performance in Las Vegas. She was among the first members of Congress to praise him following his decision to sit out the 2016 race.
"I know this decision was a very difficult one for him, and I am so glad he will continue speaking out strongly about the importance of building on the success of this administration,’’ said Boxer.
Biden made his announcement a day before Clinton testifies before a House Benghazi committee that could also be a critical moment in her campaign.

Biden said he concluded that time had run out to mount a credible bid. National polls show Clinton remains the strong favorite, with at least a 20-point lead over Sanders in many polls. She’s also erased Sanders’ advantage in the one state where he was leading her, according to a new survey out of New Hampshire.
Jim Manley, a Democratic strategist and former aide to Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, said on Fox News that Biden "had no money. He had no fundraising. He had no political operation.’’
Biden made clear he was not declining a run in order to clear a path for Clinton.
In addition to expressing his plan to remain engaged in the political process, Biden appeared to jab at Clinton for her comments last week about Republicans.
"I don't think we should look at Republicans as our enemies. They are our opposition. They're not our enemies,’’ he said.

Former Pennsylvania governor Ed Rendell, a Democrat, said any bitterness between Biden and his supporters and the Clinton campaign is unlikely to linger. Clinton spokesman Nick Merrill took to Twitter to clarify that Clinton called Biden after his Rose Garden speech.
"I don’t think Joe will keep it up, if it was his intention,’’ Rendell said on MSNBC. "He knows that Hillary Clinton’s going to be the nominee’’ and "preserve the Obama-Biden legacy.’’
There was just no political space for the vice president to get in, he said.
"I’m not sure he had the heart for what essentially had to become a very personal campaign,’’ said Rendell.
Follow @HeidiPrzybyla on Twitter.

A motion to allow Artur Davis to run as a Democratic candidate was denied by the executive board of the State Democratic Executive Committee on Friday at the Wynfrey Hotel in Hoover, Ala., but Davis will take the ruling to court as early as next week.
Davis went before the board seeking an allowance for him to run as a Democrat in the Montgomery County Commission District 1 race.
Davis left after the show-cause hearing and before the vote was publicly announced, but submitted a statement signaling legal action afterward.

"Joe Reed won round one on his home court,” Davis said of the Alabama Democratic Conference chairman via email. “The next rounds will be in the court of law, where legal standards and fair treatment are decisive, as opposed to old political grudges. Reed and his allies apparently think that double standards are just another weapon to be used against an opponent: I believe a fair minded judge and eventually the Alabama Supreme Court will decide that double standards are wrong, no matter who applies them."
The “double standards” comment from Davis is in reference to Davis’ argument that no person has ever been denied re-entry into the Democratic Party after going before the board.
“The board has never closed the door on anybody until this moment,” Davis said in his hearing, predicting the eventual outcome.
Reed said the decision was because the board didn’t see Davis being an asset to the Democratic Party.
“Party rule says that a person coming back must show that he’d be an asset to the Democratic Party,” Reed said. “The board didn’t believe he’d be an asset.”
Davis said he has retained law firm Balch and Bingham and expects them to file early next week for an “emergency injunction.”
Reed said Davis has every right to do so.
“I respect his right to do it,” Reed said in response. “I also respect the party’s ability to make its own decision.”
Davis, on the other hand, sees his actions as an example of being a “good Democrat.”

“A good Democrat will fight for equal treatment, and that is what I will be doing,” Davis said. “Judges are elected and not free from political pressure themselves, but I have to trust the legal system to put politics aside and look at the facts and the law."

Davis pointed to the Democratic Party making Radney Rule exceptions for Greg Griffin, Parker Griffith, William Shashy and Bobby Bright as examples why the motion should be approved during the hearing.
After the motion was denied, SDEC Chairwoman Nancy Worley and Dr. Tyna Davis expressed hope that Davis would earn the trust of the party by continuing to support it.

“I have great admiration for Nancy and Tyna, have known them both for years, and I am sure they appreciate that it is not them, but Dr. Reed, who has put this matter on a course to litigation,” Davis said.
At last, the Democrats debut in prime time.

The first Democratic debate Tuesday night -- in Vegas, no less -- will turn the political conversation to a party whose primary contest has been largely eclipsed by the endlessly diverting competition.

For months, the Republicans have hogged the presidential limelight with their overstuffed, sideshow-laden primary campaign. Dominated by the antics of one Donald Trump, but with no shortage of subplots revolving around the gaffe-prone yet high-polling Ben Carson, the steely Carly Fiorina, the endlessly faltering Jeb Bush, the smart money pick Marco Rubio and so many more, the GOP battle royal has concentrated attention like the proverbial highway collision. At times you want to avert your eyes, but you just can't.

Not that the Democrats have been completely invisible in the media. There's the occasional development in the ongoing saga of frontrunner Hillary Clinton and her ill-fated decision to use a private email account while secretary of State. There's the surprising success of Sen. Bernie Sanders, a socialist from Vermont who is generating excitement, drawing massive crowds and steadily rising in the polls. And there's the will-he-or-won't-he soap opera starring Vice President Biden, who shows signs of overtaking noted Danish prince Hamlet and the late New York governor Mario "A Mind is a Terrible Thing to Make Up" Cuomo as the king of indecision.
But there is little question that they have taken a backseat to The Trump Show so far.

Tuesday night's confab is sponsored by CNN and Facebook and will be moderated by CNN's Anderson Cooper. In the first Republican debate, Fox News' trio of Megyn Kelly, Chris Wallace and Bret Baier distinguished themselves with tough, serious questions for the combatants. During the second Republican debate on CNN, Jake Tapper sought to get the candidates to square off over their disagreements.

But Cooper is telegraphing a kinder, gentler approach Tuesday night. "I'm always uncomfortable with that notion of setting people up in order to kind of promote some sort of a face-off," he said Sunday on CNN's Reliable Sources. "I think these are all serious people. This is a serious debate. They want to talk about the issues. And I want to give them an opportunity to do that."
A radical notion, but perhaps not without merit!

No doubt spurred by the Trump factor, the first two GOP debates attracted huge audiences, far larger than in the past. About 24 million tuned in to debate #1 on Fox, making it the most-watched non-sports event in the history of cable television. About 22.9 million watched #2, giving CNN the largest audience in its history.

But without his magnetic presence, Trump warns, the Democratic conclave won't be a similar graveyard smash. "I think people are going to turn it on for a couple of minutes and then fall asleep," he toldFox and Friends Monday, adding with his customary modesty that someone at CNN had told him, "We have to put Donald Trump in this debate."

In the absence of the bombastic one, there's no question that all eyes will be on Clinton on Tuesday night. She has been the prohibitive favorite for months, just as she was in the 2008 primary before she was steamrollered by Barack Obama. Her ham-fisted response to the email controversy has hurt her, to the point that Sanders leads in New Hampshire. So which Clinton will show up? The defensive, legalistic, off-putting Clinton of the email wars? Or the relaxed Clinton who was so appealing on Saturday Night Live?
Either way, it's important to remember that Clinton has done a lot of these and for the most part has proven to be an effective debater.

Sanders has certainly been the Democratic phenom of the season. It's not often you hear a 74-year-old, perpetually rumpled, gravelly voiced socialist described as a "rock star," but Sanders has stirred up that kind of enthusiasm.

His task is to broaden his appeal and to show that his lefty views are not too far out there, that he can come across as someone a large number of people can picture as a plausible person to be working out of the Oval Office.

Clinton and Sanders haven't gone after each other with the ardor with which their Republican counterparts have brawled. That may be the role of Martin O'Malley, the former Maryland governor and Baltimore mayor who has long been waging a serious campaign, with little to show for it. While O'Malley has the requisite public policy bona fides, that often doesn't translate into campaign trail success, as a South Carolinian named Lindsey Graham could tell him.

O'Malley has to start making headway soon if he is going to be a factor, as do fellow second-tier candidates Jim Webb, a former Virginia senator, and Lincoln Chafee, a former Rhode Island senator and governor (and former Republican).
And since the Democratic National Committee reprehensibly has limited the number of debates to six, far fewer than the GOP total, the candidates have to make every one count.
Follow USA TODAY columnist Rem Rieder on Twitter @remrieder

U.S. Reps. Ann Kirkpatrick and Ruben Gallego announced Wednesday they will join their fellow Democrats in supporting the Iran nuclear agreement, leaving the Arizona delegation split along party lines.

U.S. Rep. Kyrsten Sinema, D-Ariz., who represents a Tempe swing district, is the only member of the state's Washington, D.C., delegation who has yet to publicly disclose how she will vote on the divisive foreign policy issue. A Sinema spokeswoman did not return messages Wednesday.

The first congressional votes on a GOP proposal to block the agreement are expected this week. Arizona's five Republican representatives and two senators oppose the deal. The three House Democrats had been on the fence for weeks.
Kirkpatrick and Gallego issued lengthy statements to explain their positions, as debate over the deal rages.

Kirkpatrick is likely to face questions about her support on the campaign trail as she seeks the seat of U.S. Sen. John McCain, who spoke against the deal Wednesday on the Senate floor. Around the same time, Republican presidential contenders Ted Cruz and Donald Trump held a rally on the Capitol lawn to protest the agreement.

Kirkpatrick said the deal is not perfect but is the United States' best diplomatic opportunity to prevent greater conflict. The agreement "blocks Iran's path to a nuclear weapon, protects Israel and launches a historic diplomatic agreement that prepares us for the future in an increasingly volatile world," she said in a written statement.
Kirkpatrick called for vigorous enforcement of the deal's provisions to prevent Iran from developing nuclear capabilities and for advancing agreements with Israel to strengthen its military.
Gallego also noted that the deal has "flaws" but is the "only credible means of halting Iran’s nuclear program."

Gallego warned that if Congress rejects the agreement, sanctions against Iran could crumble and the United States could lose all leverage except for military force. He praised the cooperation of five nations that negotiated the deal with Iran.

"As a combat veteran of the Iraq War, I strongly believe we must not repeat the mistakes of the past by forsaking the hard work of coalition-building in favor of unilateral action," Gallego said in a written statement.
Israel will be safer with Iran in check, he said, noting he visited Israel on a congressional junket this summer and spoke with leaders including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
McCain said he opposes the deal because it will pave Iran's path to a nuclear capability and embolden its military ambitions.
"This deal is not in our national security interests, and Congress should reject it," he said.
McCain's campaign also criticized Kirkpatrick for supporting the agreement, calling it "dangerous and wrong" in a written statement.

“By endorsing this bad deal with Iran, Congresswoman Kirkpatrick is proving herself to be a rubber stamp for President Obama's failed foreign policy -- the last thing Arizona and America need in this dangerous world,” the campaign said in the statement.

Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, the two candidates atop national and early state polls, have their first chance Tuesday to duel in person on trade, income inequality and other top issues of Democratic voters at the party's first debate in Las Vegas.

In recent weeks, Clinton has crept closer to Sanders on a number of more liberal policies. She came out in opposition to both the Keystone XL pipeline and the Trans-Pacific trade deal — which she previously supported — as she tries to neutralize an unexpectedly potent challenge from the self-described democratic socialist Vermont senator.
The debate, the first of six for Democrats, will also feature former Maryland governor Martin O'Malley, former Virginia senator Jim Webb and former Rhode Island governor Lincoln Chafee.

There are still big differences between Clinton and Sanders, and they’ll come into focus during the candidate forum. Sanders wants to break up the big banks, while Clinton would penalize bankers who violate the law. He would also raise the minimum wage higher than she would, to $15 an hour, and expand health care coverage through a major Medicare expansion. She says she wants to improve the Affordable Care Act. Clinton also voted for the Iraq War as a senator, while Sanders opposed it while in the House.
Yet Clinton’s greatest challenge is probably not on any specific issue.
Rather, she'll need to convince Democratic voters that her recent leftward drift is genuine and not just political opportunism amid the heat of a primary battle.

In an appearance Sunday on NBC’s Meet the Press, Sanders previewed his case against Clinton, the front-runner. "People have to contrast my consistency and my willingness to stand up to Wall Street and corporations, big corporations, with the secretary,’’ he said.

"It is going to be tough to walk away from her role’’ as the nation’s former top diplomat on issues like Keystone and trade, said Bill Buck, a Democratic strategist who is unaligned with a candidate. "She needs to walk a fine line to avoid a mistake.’’

As for the the other debate participants, O’Malley may have the most at stake, with polls showing him stuck below 1%. A breakout moment may be his only hope of gaining the traction needed to secure the money and endorsements necessary to continue his bid.

For Clinton, the debate is also a chance to shift the focus away from her use of a private email server while she served as secretary of State, a controversy that’s dragged down her poll ratings, and on to her policy proposals. A weak or strong performance might also tip the hand of Vice President Biden, who is still mulling a decision on whether to enter the race.

Clinton is trying to demonstrate her commitment to progressives without alienating the wealthy donors her campaign will rely on far more than Sanders, whose financial support comes mostly from small, Internet-based donors.

For Sanders, the challenge is to convert his populist fire on the stump into a more personal and engaging approach that draws contrasts with Clinton’s past positions without appearing to directly attack her.

The one issue on which he may find himself on defense is guns. While Sanders now supports expanding background checks, he has a long record of opposing gun control, including the 1994 Brady Law that established mandatory background checks.
"I would push Sanders hard on guns,’’ said Buck. "It’s a bigger liability in the primaries than the Iraq War vote.’’
The debate location, Nevada, is a showcase of sorts for an argument Clinton aides make that the Sanders threat is overblown.

Once the battle moves from overwhelmingly older and white Iowa and New Hampshire, they say, her grip on the nomination will tighten. In Nevada, the first early-voting state with a large Latino population, Clinton has a 16-point lead over Sanders, according to a recent CNN/ORC poll.
The advantage widens to 22 points without Biden in the race. Her lead in South Carolina, the first Southern voting primary state, is even wider, at 25 points over Biden and 31 points over Sanders.
Until recently, Clinton has behaved as a prohibitive front-runner, largely ignoring Sanders.

Then Sanders came within $2 million of Clinton’s fundraising totals over the past quarter and has continued to draw large crowds. Even if he’s unlikely to secure the nomination, he’s already succeeded in pushing Clinton leftward on many issues in a race that, several months ago, seemed like it might not be much of one.
For their part, Republicans want to keep Democrats, and specifically Sanders’ supporters, focused on Clinton’s emails.

In an ad released ahead of the debate, the Republican National Committee highlights Clinton’s previous comments that she "did not email classified material to anyone.’’ As the State Department and other agencies review her emails, officials have decided to classify hundreds of the emails after the fact.
Follow @HeidiPrzybyla on Twitter
BIDEN HIS TIME

Hillary Clinton’s mostly surefooted debate performance in the Democrats’ first presidential Tuesday night seemed to help her quite a lot, chiefly by weakening the argument that Vice President Biden should get into the race because the front-runner is dangerously vulnerable.

Clinton was the best prepared and most deeply knowledgeable of the five Democrats, displaying a mid-campaign form and just enough humor and fire to make her look like the front-runner the polls still say she is. The main arguments for a Biden candidacy have been that Clinton was losing altitude and that the party needed an insurance policy if she continued to decline or if her email troubles spun out of control.

That could still happen, but perception counts for a lot in politics, and her strong effort Tuesday could help dispel doubts. Biden, meanwhile, is exhausting the party’s patience by continuing to dither about whether he’ll run. Now reports say he’s trying to figure out whether he can wait until November, after Clinton's appearance next week before the House Benghazi Committee, to make up his mind.

Clinton was hardly flawless Tuesday night. When she got an obvious question she should have been more than prepared for — whether electing another Clinton to the White House would be just stale dynasty politics — she stumbled through an unsatisfactory response about the first woman president being the ultimate outsider.

Nor did she manage to decisively handle the controversy over the email system she used as secretary of State until rival Bernie Sanders threw her a lifeline by saying, “The American people are sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails!”
But if Biden was watching from the sidelines, waiting for Clinton to give him an opening and rationale to jump into the race, she didn't provide much of one.
HEY, BIG SPENDERS

In his 1996 State of the Union address, Bill Clinton famously said “the era of big government is over.” Gauging by Tuesday’s debate, this year’s cast of Democratic candidates — including Clinton’s wife — didn’t get the message.

Like most debates, this one touched on a wide range of topics. But when it focused on issues such as Social Security, Medicare and college tuition, it seemed to have settled on a new slogan: “Spend, baby, spend.”

The indefatigable Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, of course, led the pack. He pushed his plans to increase Social Security benefits by an average of $65 per month, pay every dime of the cost of students attending public universities, and expand Medicare to make it available to anyone.

But the others weren’t far behind. Clinton and former Maryland governor Martin O’Malley, the most plausible of the three lesser-known candidates, want to expand Social Security. Both would pour money into subsidizing tuition. And O’Malley has a sweeping health plan that makes Obamacare look tame.

The utter impracticality of all this is impressive. Candidates are pushing enormous new spending at a time when Congress won’t even commit to funding roads for more than a few weeks at a time. They’re pushing new entitlements as the answer when existing benefit programs already account for nearly two-thirds of all federal spending.
In reality, the taxes they propose (and more) would be needed just to maintain benefit programs on their current trajectory as the Baby Boom generation retires.

Although income inequality is a serious problem, it would be nice if Democrats could acknowledge that not all problems are caused by Republicans and Wall Street. The country has serious challenges that stem from its wildly inefficient health care system and its appetite for taxing the working to pay for the retired. Rather than spending more, they should demand more results from what is being spent.
ON DIFFERENT PLANETS
Even beyond taxes and spending, Tuesday’s debate was yet another vivid reminder that on a wide array of issues, Democrats are from Mars and Republicans are from Venus.

At the two GOP debates that came before the Democrats got their chance in Las Vegas, the candidates generally competed to see who was the most pro-gun and pro-life — and the most anti-illegal immigrant and anti-climate change action. At the Democratic debate, it was generally the other way around.

Hillary Clinton, who has lurched to the left in her primary race against Bernie Sanders, described herself as “a progressive who likes to get things done” and tries to find common ground. Given Republicans’ long history of animosity toward Clinton, however, it’s hard to see her getting more cooperation from Republicans in Congress than President Obama has gotten.

And in the unlikely event that the winner is Sanders, a “democratic socialist” who said the way to get things done is to elect more Democrats, the Obama era might look like a golden age of cooperation.

The parties' respective debates offer a preview of the stark choice voters will face next fall, when the eventual presidential nominees will square off. They are also a sign of the sharply divided public opinion on issues such as guns, which Sanders rightly pointed out reflects an urban-rural split in addition to an ideological one.
As the Republicans run to the right and the Democrats to the left, the prospect for finding centrist solutions to the nation's challenges grows ever dimmer.

Iowa Democratic U.S. Senate hopeful Thomas Fiegen’s support for presidential candidate Bernie Sanders was cut from his introduction at a major party event last month, Fiegen claimed in an online conversation with supporters this week.

Fiegen, an attorney from Clarence, told a supporter during an “Ask Me Anything” session on the social website Reddit on Wednesday that his endorsement for Sanders was “edited out” of the short biographical blurb read by Iowa Democratic Party Chairwoman Andy McGuire during the party’s annual Jefferson-Jackson Dinner on Oct. 24.
The fundraiser is the largest party event of the year and was attended by all three Democratic presidential candidates and thousands of party activists.

Fiegen presented the omitted endorsement in his AMA session and elsewhere as evidence of a divide between a party establishment that supports presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton and a grassroots that backs Sanders. In an interview with the Register Thursday, he described a widespread perception that "the invisible thumb of the Democratic Party is on Hillary’s side" in the presidential nomination race.
Also visit: DesMoinesRegister.com/IowaCaucuses | Candidate tracker and calendar in Iowa | Sign up for Caucuses Newsletter

“My question is: Why is it that my endorsement of Bernie was in essence censored?" he said on Thursday. "In the big scheme of things this a blip, but the perception is that the Democratic machine is trying to tilt this election to the point that people who support an alternative candidate are being silenced.”
He said he responded at the dinner by waving a Sanders campaign sign from the stage — and won a big response from the crowd.
A spokesman for the party said dinner organizers had a policy against including presidential candidate endorsements in state-level candidate or congressional delegation introductions.
U.S. Rep. Dave Loebsack was similarly admonished not to include his endorsement of Clinton in his introduction, party spokesman Sam Lau said.
Fiegen is one of several candidates vying for the Democratic nomination in next year's U.S. Senate race. The winner will almost certainly face long-time incumbent Republican Chuck Grassley.
Letters to the editor:

It was so refreshing to hear five intelligent, accomplished adult candidates debate issues. They not only didn't rip each other to shreds, but they also honored and acknowledged one another — all the while campaigning and outlining their plans. Bravo!
I didn't understand all the issues by a long shot, but my jaw was hanging to the floor and my heart was singing while listening to a civil, informative debate.

Meanwhile, I was watching Donald Trump tweet like a schoolyard bully, sounding like a thug. The Democrats handled themselves with class, and laid out their records, opinions and plans on the big issues. I was so proud to see grown-ups at the grown-up table for a change. I could see these seasoned professionals working together on a critical piece of legislation.
Denise Martin; Lake Oswego, Ore.
POLICING THE USA: A look at race, justice, media

After watching the debate, I told my friend that Hillary Clinton would likely make a fine Democratic president — meaning that she would do just as much (or just as little) as all of our other Democratic (and Republican) presidents have of late. She would pander to the wealthy donors she has; she would inch along, changing little; she would talk big and act small; and she would certainly worsen the divide between Republicans and Democrats. This is unacceptable and will foster no real meaningful change for the environment, for class and race relations, for free public education, for our wonderful country.

It’s time that we actually start listening to the senator from Vermont because, whether we like how Bernie Sanders is delivering his message, he’s proposing that we make real, meaningful changes right now — not in 20 or 50 years. These changes would directly, positively impact every American.

The winner of Tuesday night’s Democratic debate was the American people. They were finally given a front-row seat to the most genuine politician that I’ve seen in my life, a front-row seat to the possibility of real change. Hopefully, they’ll be wise enough to realize how big of a deal this is and be forward-thinking enough to get involved.
Andrew Fersch; Exeter, N.H.

I do care about the email controversy, as it provides clues to a lack of judgment and potential neglect of responsibility while in office. — Douglas Williams

I didn't hear a debate. I didn't think Anderson Cooper held control. After an hour, I switched channels. — Marcia Lindsey

With absentee ballots counted, it appears Democrats in the town of Sweden have eked out enough votes to capture two seats on the town board.

After officials with the Monroe County Board of Elections on Tuesday counted affidavit ballots and absentee ballots received by the Nov. 10 deadline, board candidate Mary Rich ended up with 1,153 total votes, giving her the edge over Republican candidates Peter Sharpe and Donald Roberts, who had 1,119 and 1,137 votes, respectively.

There are likely not enough outstanding military absentee ballots — which must be postmarked by Nov. 2 and received by the Board of Elections by Nov. 16 in order to be counted — to sway the results, barring court challenges to any other ballots.
Democrat Lori Skoog, also competing for one of the the two slots up for grabs in this year's election, ended up with 1,174 votes.
Results are still unofficial until they are certified on Nov. 27.
If the results hold, this election will mark the first time in nearly two decades that there have been any Democrats in Sweden's Republican-dominated town government.

Republican Town Supervisor Rob Carges held on to his seat this year, securing victory over challenger Annie Crane by 103 votes, according to the unofficial results. Totals in that race were: 1,201 votes for Carges and 1,097 votes for Crane.
MCDERMOT@Gannett.com
House Democrats propose spending an additional $2 billion over the next four years on Indiana's roads and bridges — but the plan would dip deeply into the state's savings account to do it.

The proposal, announced Monday, represents twice the $1 billion in new spending that Republican Gov. Mike Pence proposed last month. It also provides funding for city and county roads, unlike the governor's plan.

"The governor put out a small proposal regarding our roads just a few weeks ago. It was what I would characterize as a get-off-my-rear-end proposal," Scott Pelath, D-Michigan City, said. “Our plan is based on a simple concept. Every tax you pay at your gas station should go to fix your street or highway or bridge."
But he acknowledged that the plan also would require dipping more deeply into the state's $2 billion reserve fund.
That drew criticism from House Republicans and the Pence administration.

"Sadly, the plan presented today by House Democrats forces Hoosiers to choose between cutting $500 million from the general fund for vital services like K-12 tuition support, teacher pensions, Medicaid and state hospitals or going broke in four years," Pence spokesman Matt Lloyd said. "That is irresponsible and not serious.”

The House Democrats' plan would shift the entire 7 percent state sales tax on gasoline toward highway spending. Right now, only a penny of that 7 cents on the dollar tax goes toward roads. The rest goes into the general fund, where it is used for other services.

To prevent an erosion in those other services, Democrats want to backstop the general fund losses with money from the state's reserves and future surpluses. Pelath said he doesn't believe the state needs $2 billion in a reserve account. He said $1.5 billion would be sufficient.

"We simply believe the revenue should be redirected and reinvested in a way that will allow for economic growth in the future," he said. "We are limiting our economic growth because we’re not re-investing in something that’s so fundamental."
About 53 percent of the $2 billion would go toward state roads, with 47 percent going to city and county roads, Pelath said.
Pence's plan includes no money for local governments, which operate the vast majority of the state's roads, though they are typically less traveled than those maintained by the state.

The governor's plan would be funded through $241 million in state reserves, $240 million in bonding, $6.5 million in savings from refinancing current bonds and $450 million in new spending authorized by lawmakers in future budgets.
Neither plan calls for new taxes.
The House Democrats' plan represents the latest punch in what is likely to be a months-long political fight over the condition of the state's bridges and highways.

Unions and Democrats — including presumed nominee for governor John Gregg — have blamed Pence for the month-long shutdown of 33 miles of I-65 due to a broken bridge and tens of millions of dollars in potentially faulty road projects first disclosed in The Indianapolis Star in September.

Both parties agree that more money is needed to maintain the state's roads amid stagnating revenue from state and federal fuel taxes. Some estimates say the gap between current funding what is needed to maintain roads and bridges in their current condition is about $1 billion a year. Lawmakers are expected to take up the issue during the 2016 General Assembly, which begins in January.

Democratic presidential hopeful Martin O'Malley will speak at the Polk County Democrats' Fall Dinner on Oct. 9, his campaign announced Friday.

The dinner will be the former Maryland governor's 14th trip to Iowa since his launching his campaign in May. O'Malley and rival Jim Webb, a former Virginia senator, both spoke at the county party's annual spring awards in April.

O'Malley has struggled to climb in the polls within range of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Vermont U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders. But he told the Register in September that he's confident his grassroots approach is winning supporters.
MORE:
The fall dinner will be held at the Varied Industries Building on the Iowa State Fairgrounds. Doors to the event open at 5:30 p.m., with the program beginning at 6:30.
The party's website says all declared Democratic candidates have been invited to speak. Information on how to RSVP is available on www.polkdems.com
Democratic candidates for top offices in next week’s election continue to raise far more money than their Republican opponents

Democratic gubernatorial candidate Jack Conway reported Monday night that his campaign had raised $916,681 during the period between Oct. 3 and Oct. 16, bringing to just over $7 million the amount it raised for the general election.
The Conway campaign reported it still had about $800,000 in cash-on-hand as of Oct. 19.

This compares to $268,145 that the Republican candidate for governor Matt Bevin reported raising during the same period. Through the entire campaign Bevin has reported raising nearly $2 million, but about half of that is money Bevin has loaned his campaign.
Bevin reported having $341,440 on hand as of Oct. 19.

In the race for attorney general, Democrat Andy Beshear, son of Gov. Steve Beshear, reported raising an additional $131,779 earlier this month. That brought his total for the campaign to just over $2.8 million. It reported a balance on hand of $462,648 as of Oct. 19.
Republican candidate for attorney general Whitney Westerfield reported raising $56,598 during the period and had raised $205,630 for the entire campaign. It reported $33,764 on hand as of Oct. 19.
Reports of the four campaigns were filed with the Kentucky Registry of Election Finance which posted them on its website.

But in addition to fundraising by these campaigns, all of these four candidates are back by big super PACs running independent advertising campaigns on their behalf. And the huge money edge of Democrats is reduced when the spending of these super PACs is accounted for.
Republicans vow to repeal and replace Obamacare. That, of course, raises the question: Replace it with what?
That, however, isn’t the most pertinent question about Obamacare. The more pertinent question is: What are Democrats going to propose to fix Obamacare before it financially bleeds to death?
In reality, Republicans are unlikely to acquire sufficient political power to repeal and replace Obamacare. At a minimum, it would require control of the presidency and both houses of Congress.

But, so long as the Senate filibuster rule remains in place, even that wouldn’t be enough. A repeal of Obamacare and replacing it with the kind of alternatives Republicans are discussing would undoubtedly be filibustered by Democrats.

Which means that repealing and replacing Obamacare actually requires Republicans controlling 60 seats in the Senate. And no political prognosticator is predicting anything close to that coming out of the next election.
However, there is enough experience now with Obamacare to know that it is not sustainable. The finances just don’t work.

Insurance companies lost big on Obamacare policies in the first two years. They anticipate big losses next year as well. The largest insurer in the country, UnitedHealth, announced that it wasn’t going to market its Obamacare policies for next year and will consider dropping out of the program the following year.

The problem is that the young and healthy aren’t signing up, despite the fine that must be paid if uninsured. That isn’t expected to change next year. Projected growth in Obamacare policies is anemic.

The amount of the fine ratchets up over time, which might induce more signups. That, however, is offset by market forces making the products offered on the Obamacare exchanges progressively less attractive.

Insurers have responded to their losses by increasing premiums and deductibles and restricting provider networks. So, people are being asked to pay more for less. That makes gaming even stiffer individual mandate fines a worthwhile endeavor for those not seriously or chronically sick.
This is not something that will correct itself with time. It’s a flaw built into Obamacare’s design.

Obamacare was sold as a safety net program to ensure that the seriously or chronically sick didn’t go without care or go broke receiving it. A program limited to that could be financially sustainable.
But Obamacare was far more than a safety net program. It rewrote the rules for the entire health insurance market.

Obamacare dictates what insurance policies cover, in and out of its exchanges. It mandates that a wide range of preventative care programs be provided without copays. And it sharply limits the ability of insurers to differentially price based upon anticipated utilization.

The movement to high deductible policies was probably going to take place organically anyway. And it’s actually a beneficial trend. Insurance is supposed to cover big, unanticipated expenses, not routine stuff.

But Obamacare turbocharged and distorted the movement. Having to cover a suite of benefits for everyone, and having to provide first-dollar coverage without copays for many of them, drives up costs. And that results in higher deductibles for things for which they are permitted.

So, rather than provide a safety net for those seriously or chronically sick, Obamacare sharply restricted choice and pricing in the individual market. That created perverse incentives for consumers and insurers.
For the most part, the only individual insurance available is comprehensive. Except for a narrow exception for young people, the catastrophic coverage many would prefer is illegal.
And taxpayers are subsidizing comprehensive rather than catastrophic coverage. Roughly 85 percent of the policies sold on the Obamacare exchanges receive a taxpayer subsidy.

The design flaws mean that Obamacare policies will be increasingly costly and unappealing to anyone not chronically or seriously sick, or without eligibility for large taxpayer subsidies. These are reinforcing trends that can’t be fixed with the individual mandate stick. The stick would have to be too big to be politically viable.
On the right, there are policy wonks developing Obamacare alternatives and politicians advancing them.
On the left, there doesn’t appear to be anyone working on how to fix Obamacare before it financially bleeds to death.
That’s a mistake.
Reach Robb at robert.robb@arizonarepublic.com.
Dozens of South Dakota Democrats gathered in the dining room of a historic hotel Saturday night to rally and air grievances against the majority party.
About 100 Democrats came together from across the state for the first Buffalo Round Up Dinner at the Hotel Alex Johnson.

For $65 a plate or $500 for a table of 8, attendees could partake in dishes reminiscent of the theme including ribs and Shepherd’s pie served buffet style. And insults about Republican elected officials and candidates were also on the menu Saturday night.

The executive director of the state Democratic Party Suzanne Jones Pranger was quick to call Republican lawmakers U.S. Sen. John Thune and Rep. Kristi Noem Washington insiders. And party co-chair Joe Lowe critiqued the Republican presidential candidates as a “clown car” headed nowhere.
Both Lowe and party chairwoman Ann Tornberg called on the attendees to challenge Republicans and to rally behind Democrats in 2016 and 2018 elections.
“We’re on the right side of the issues, you guys,” Lowe told the attendees before dinner was served. “We need to take them (Republicans) to task. Don’t let them control the narrative anymore.”
But with just more than 13 months until the 2016 election, the Democrats still haven’t found a candidate to challenge Thune. And none was immediately recommended Saturday.
State Rep. Paula Hawks, D-Hartford, has announced she’ll challenge U.S. Rep. Kristi Noem, R-South Dakota, for her House seat in 2016.

And the Democrats recognized that state voter registration numbers don’t fall in their favor. According to the most recent numbers published by the South Dakota secretary of state’s office, registered Republican voters far outnumber Democrats.

As of September 1 of this year, 243,881 South Dakota voters, or about 46 percent, registered as Republicans whereas 175,172, or roughly 33 percent, registered as Democrats. An additional 111,577 South Dakota voters, roughly 21 percent, registered as non-partisan, independent or not belonging to a party.
Darlis, 63, and Tom Halverson, 70, said they made the drive 5-hour drive to Rapid City from Sioux Falls to reunite with friends in the party and to renew a sense of belonging.
“It’s important for us to get together and see that there are still some Democrats left in the state,” Darlis Halverson said. “Sometimes you feel alone.”
Halverson joked about the Democrats in attendance saying many were older and had been working on campaigns together since the 60s and 70s.
“Our younger people all leave the state,” she said. “Now it’s just us older people out here.”
Jake Kammerer, a self-described conservative Democrat from Silver City, said he was confident that eventually the power structure in Pierre would change.
“What we’ve had to put up with for 40 years in this state is one-party rule,” Kammerer said. “And that will change. Everything changes.”
Hawks, Rep. Kevin Killer, D-Pine Ridge and Sen. Billie Sutton, D-Burke also spoke at the event.
Follow Dana Ferguson on Twitter @bydanaferguson
Paul M. Booth, Brian Garry, Nicholas Hollan and Paul Sohi are running for the Democratic nomination for the 31st District House seat held by Denise Driehaus, who is term-limited.

The fundamental core of American politics is that the American people have the right to choose their elected officials. Inherently, a primary election allows the voters who identify with a specific party to choose which candidate will carry their banner into the general election.

The Hamilton County Democratic Party is fortunate to have several Democratic candidates who are passionate about serving the constituents of the 31st District. Paul Booth, Brian Garry, Nicholas Hollan, Brigid Kelly, Ben Lindy and Paul Sohi are all candidates who espouse Democratic ideals and would faithfully represent the 31st District in Columbus. All of these candidates are well qualified and the residents of the 31st District would be well served by any of these candidates.

In the spirit of party unity, five candidates requested that the Democratic Party refrain from endorsing a candidate until after the voters of the 31st District have made their voices heard in the primary election.
This request is not without precedent, and a clear example can be seen in this very district. In 2012, there was a contested primary and the party did not endorse.

Recently, a nominating committee was formed to interview the Democratic candidates for the 31st District and make an endorsement recommendation to the Democratic Party Executive Committee. Four candidates declined to interview because they felt that the party should not endorse.
Despite our request, the committee moved forward with a vote but fell short of the two-thirds majority required for passage.
The Executive Committee is expected to act on the report of the nominating committee at its meeting Saturday. We hope the members will vote for no endorsement.

We believe in the core principles of democracy: citizen participation, equality and fair and open elections. The Democratic Party has always fought for voters’ rights. An endorsement is not in the best interest of the people in the 31st District. They should have the opportunity to decide for themselves who would best represent them.

Two hours on a live debate stage Tuesday should be ample time for the Democratic underdogs battling front-runner Hillary Clinton to make a beneficial impression on voters — or to acutely disappoint them, politics watchers say.

"The debates will alter the race," said Stephanie Cutter, a Democratic strategist and top staffer in the President Obama's 2012 re-election campaign. "Clinton will no longer be running against herself — the debates will force a choice, but only if she strongly stands by her positions, record and beliefs and doesn't get pushed to the left by others."

Nearly 23 million viewers tuned in for the last GOP debate, featuring the smash-mouth antics of Donald Trump and his rivals' attempts to weaken him. Will the Democrats be able to engage as many people for their first debate, set to begin at 9 p.m. ET (coverage starts at 8:30) on Tuesday in Las Vegas?

"Hillary should appear in character as 'Val,' " joked Tracy Sefl, a former senior adviser to Ready for Hillary, the super PAC that laid the groundwork for Clinton's campaign. Clinton portrayed a bartender named Val in a recent Saturday Night Live sketch.

Those competing Tuesday are Clinton, a former secretary of State; Vermont U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, her closest rival in the polls; former Maryland governor Martin O'Malley; former Virginia senator Jim Webb; and former Rhode Island governor Lincoln Chafee.

Executives with debate host CNN have said they'll squeeze in an extra podium for the still-deciding Joe Biden if the vice president files last-minute paperwork for a 2016 presidential bid before the debate begins.
CNN reported recently that the vice president was likely to skip the opening debate. Still, the Biden question mark adds drama, said Grant Woodard, an Iowa political operative and lawyer.
"If he is there," Woodard said, "it will be one hell of a show."

The debate comes as Sanders has closed the polling gap on Clinton in Iowa, where party caucuses kick off the nation's presidential voting, and overtaken her in New Hampshire, home of the first primary.
Here are six things to watch for:
1. Steam from the Hillary grilling

If the CNN debate moderators treat this as their chance to grill Clinton on live TV instead of carrying out an actual debate where other candidates are allotted plenty of time to make their case, "Democrats will likely be frustrated," said Pat Rynard, a former Democratic campaign staffer from Iowa.
2. The Biden shadow
Even if he's not on the stage, "Joe is a real part of the debate," said Democrat Patty Judge, a former Iowa lieutenant governor.

"Sadly," added Rynard, "in terms of the media narrative, nothing in the debate may matter if Biden announces his intentions the next day and wipes out all the coverage. Hopefully that doesn't happen, but it's near when Biden has to make a decision for ballot purposes."
3. Sanders' fidelity to fixed talking points
The liberal messenger could miss an opportunity if he expounds only a dry, policy-heavy message, Democrats said.

"He really refuses to deviate much from his economic inequality shtick on the campaign trail — which, to be fair, is a very powerful message that has gotten him far," said Rynard, who writes about presidential politics on the website Iowa Starting Line. "(But) debates tend to favor interaction and candidates quick on their toes who can give punchy responses."
4. Two debates in one
One debate will likely be a policy contest between Clinton and Sanders, both of whom have declined to stray into personal attacks, observers said.

"She will continue to move herself to the left in order to appeal to undecideds and to those who are leaning to Sanders but not firmly in his camp," Judge said of Clinton. "She will also try to continue to distance herself from the Obama administration to give herself room to take on Biden if he gets into the race."
The second debate could feature hard swings from the low-polling contenders, especially O'Malley, who has gotten increasingly personal in drawing contrasts with Clinton.
Watch for gun control, trade, banks and foreign policy to take center stage, said Michael Cheney, a professor of communication and economics at the University of Illinois at Springfield.
5. O'Malley's moment?
Many Democrats worry that Sanders' "socialist" label and Clinton's struggles with her email controversy would badly hinder them in the general election, Rynard said.
O'Malley has run a serious campaign and impressed Democrats who go see him. But he barely attracts national media coverage, and many voters haven't noticed him yet.
Cutter said: "This is the last best chance for Martin O'Malley."

O'Malley needs to pull votes from Sanders, she said. "If he doesn't distinguish himself as the person more likely to achieve results for a progressive agenda, rather than just a protest," Cutter said, "then he's out."
6. The invisible Democrats
It's now or never for Webb and Chafee, neither of whom do any real campaigning, Rynard said.
"At this point, they're just taking up space," he said.

Democrats said they're hesitant to take either candidate seriously when even low-polling GOP candidates such as Rick Santorum, Bobby Jindal and Lindsey Graham throw energy into reaching out to early state voters.
But debates are fertile ground for earning a bump in the polls, strategists noted.

"The best debaters," Sefl said, "are those who don't look like they rehearsed their one-liners thousands of times, and who know how to demonstrate command of the issues without being the annoying kid from class who always raised their hand to every question."

Kentucky Democrats braced for more party switches in the state House of Representatives after Rep. Denny Butler of Louisville announced that he has changed his voter registration and will run as a Republican in 2016.

The move pushes the Republicans one step closer to taking over the state House for the first time in nearly a century and underscores Democrats' problems in the wake of the Nov. 3 election that saw Matt Bevin beat Democrat Jack Conway in a near landslide.
The move, said former Sen. David Karem, will surely "embolden more Democrats" to switch parties - something that Senate President Robert Stivers predicted would happen in an interview.

"There are approximately 15 (Democratic House members) that have had some type of outreach of individuals to test the waters about a switch and Denny Butler is not on that list," said Stivers, who added that it's possible but not probable that the GOP could have the majority of the House by Jan. 5, when the General Assembly gavels into session.

What is chilling for Democrats is that when the Republicans took control of the Senate in 1999, they did it not through the ballot box but through decisions by former Democrats Dan Seum and Bob Leeper to become Republicans.
U.S. Sen. Mitch McConnell, who is credited as the architect of the modern GOP in Kentucky, hailed Butler's announcement as another sign of a Republican uprising.

"The Republican Party continues to grow in the commonwealth, and today I welcome Rep. Denny Butler to our party," he said in a statement. "I am confident he will deliver for Kentucky and do an outstanding job representing his constituents in Frankfort."
Gov. Steve Beshear, a Democrat, however, said he thinks Butler fits better as a Democrat and hopes he reconsiders.
Nonetheless, Beshear said he expects Republicans to go after more House seats.
“I’m sure that they’re working very hard on that right now,” Beshear said. "I’m very hopeful that that’s not going to happen. I don’t see that happening for this session of the General Assembly.”

In a statement, Butler, the son of late Democratic state Rep. Denver Butler and a former Louisville Metro Police officer, said he was unhappy with Democratic leadership in his fight to secure more funds for police and firefighters.

"In my continued request for the first independent audit of these funds, I am met with resistance and disregard from leaders of the Democrat Party," Butler said. "I look forward to working with Minority Leader (Jeff) Hoover to facilitate a meeting with Auditor-elect (Mike) Harmon concerning the requested audit."
He said he filed for re-election in the 38th District as a Republican "after a great deal of thought, reflection and prayer." He didn't return phone calls and text messages to his cell phone.
Hoover, of Jamestown, broke the news on his Twitter account Thursday morning when he welcomed Butler, which came shortly after he first learned of Butler's decision to switch parties.

“I certainly understood his frustration with and his disappointment with the Democrat leadership in the House, but this morning was the first I learned that he had actually switched," he said in the interview.
He said he had spoken to Butler recently, but only about policy issues. “I didn’t get him to switch,” he said.

Butler was “absolutely not” promised any committee assignments to induce him to switch parties, Hoover said. He added that he doesn’t know of any other party switches that are imminent, but he wouldn’t rule it out.

“There are several folks who have expressed frustration with the House Democrat leadership and the way things are going there, so are there some people who could do like Denny Butler did? I don’t know,” Hoover said.

State Rep. Fitz Steele, D-Hazard, who is frequently mentioned as a target for Republicans to flip, said he has no plans to become a Republican - but he doesn't try to hide his anger at the Democratic Party and particularly at President Barack Obama, who he blames for the loss of coal jobs in his part of the state.
"All the people in Perry and Harlan County elected me as a 'D'," he said. "I don't know the deal with Denny. I guess you’ll have to ask (him) but as far as me, I don’t see me going nowhere.
"... I've just lost 221 jobs here because of the Obama administration," he said. "I've never been for that administration and ... I'll fight them 'til the day I die."
Both counties in Steele's district voted against Obama in 2008 and 2012 and supported Bevin in this year's governor's race.

Butler has served in the House, where Democrats hold a slim majority, since 2013. He mainly represents southwestern Louisville in a heavily union district that supported Obama in both 2008 and 2012 and voted overwhelmingly for Conway against Bevin. That gives Democrats some hope that they can recapture the seat next November.

Prior to his switch, Democrats held a 54-46 advantage in the House, but the Democrats had been hopeful that they could increase their advantage in special elections that will be held to replace Rep. Ryan Quarles, of Georgetown, and Harmon, of Danville, after their election to statewide office this month.
House Speaker Pro Tem Jody Richards said he was shocked by Butler’s decision and that his move “certainly doesn’t help” Democrats' efforts to hold onto the House in the wake of Bevin’s election.
“I don’t know of anyone else who is planning to switch. In fact, we’ve talked with our members and no one has given us an indication that they would switch,” Richards said.
He said he had never considered Butler a possibility. “His family is very strong Democrat,” Richards said.
Butler’s father served for years in the state House and his sister, Marianne, is a Democratic member of the Louisville Metro Council. She declined to comment.
Rep. Mary Lou Marzian, D-Louisville, said she also was stunned by the news.
“He’s always seemed to me to have core values as a strong Democrat,” she said. “I’m taken aback a bit, but I’m still his friend and hopefully he may rethink it.”
Marzian said Butler may have been angered last year when the Jefferson County delegation voted to back Rep. Darryl Owens for speaker pro tem, rather than him.
“I don’t know if that made him mad or not,” she said.

Butler was a strong supporter of Democrats in the November election. He contributed $1,000 to Conway, $500 each to Auditor Adam Edelen and attorney general candidate Andy Beshear, and $250 to treasurer candidate Rick Nelson.

House Speaker Greg Stumbo, of Prestonsburg, told CN|2's Pure Politics that he believes that Butler is switching parties because of a political battle involving his brother, Matt Butler, who was running as a Democrat to replace Rep. Larry Clark, D-Louisville, who is retiring. According to the secretary of state's website, Matt Butler withdrew as a candidate Thursday.

“I know there’s been a sort of a feud down there in the district that Larry Clark represented,” Stumbo told CN|2, while attending the Kentucky Association of Counties conference in Lexington. “I assume that has something to do with it, but I hope that he will reconsider. He comes from a very long line of Democrats.”
Stumbo didn't return calls seeking comments but issued a statement promising to field a strong candidate to challenge Butler. "Our caucus remains strong," he said.

TRENTON – To the victor go the spoils.

For Democrats who tightened their control in the state Assembly in Tuesday’s elections, that means embarking on an ambitious agenda that could cause a clash with Gov. Chris Christie and Republicans over taxes.

Vincent Prieto, D-Hudson, was re-elected Assembly speaker Thursday by the Democratic caucus and said he looks forward look “to working with everyone in the weeks ahead and into the next session as we tackle some of the major problems facing our state.”

Prieto said a top priority is to resolve a gasoline tax funding shortfall for transportation projects. Christie said recently Republicans should not support any tax increases unless other taxes are lowered.

Also, Republican lawmakers have said they will vote to sustain Christie’s promised veto of an income tax increase on the wealthy, seen by Democrats as a way to prop up the pension system for public employees.

Few details for the expected battles in the upcoming legislative were fleshed out Thursday, though Republicans called on Democrats to lead the way since they won the election, picking up as many as four Assembly seats.
“What’s your plan?” Assembly Minority Leader Jon Bramnick asked.

The vote follows a special report by the Asbury Park Press on property taxes in New Jersey, which has the nation’s highest average property tax bill at $8,200. The investigation showed how property taxes rise $540 million annually, despite a 2 percent tax cut, forcing more and more families to flee the state.
Nearly 14,000 readers signed a Press petition calling on lawmakers to commit to a plan before year’s end to cut property taxes by 10 percent.
What seemed clear on Thursday, however, is the potential for a confrontation over raising taxes, which Democrats have said may be necessary.
“We need revenues in the state of New Jersey,” Prieto said. “If anybody knows me by now, I’m very straightforward and I’m very blunt in the things that I say. It gets tougher as every year goes by.”
“You can’t have something that’s revenue neutral,” he added. “How are you going to fix the roads and then take the money from somewhere else? That is a ridiculous statement.”

At issue is the state’s transportation trust fund. A variety of taxes go into the fund, including one on gasoline, but the money goes toward paying down debt from previous projects, and any new projects are financed by additional borrowing. Lawmakers say that come June 30, the fund will no longer be able to borrow for new projects.

Democrats also want the state to pay more into the public pension, but Christie, who is seeking the GOP nomination for president, has said further reforms are needed. He paid $1.3 billion in the current fiscal year despite a statute calling for a nearly $3 billion payment. The dispute is at the heart of an ongoing partisan fight in Trenton.

Bramnick and Republicans say reducing the state’s highest-in-the-nation property taxes should be a top priority, but Prieto pointed out that cuts could blow other holes in the state’s roughly $38 billion budget.

Democrats have held the majority in the Assembly since 2002 and, according to unofficial results, could hold a 52-28 majority in the upcoming 2016-17 session, the largest Democratic majority since 1979.

Both parties chose their leaders for the next two-year session. Bramnick and Senate Minority Leader Tom Kean Jr. were selected as top Republicans again. Senate President Steve Sweeney was also chosen to lead his chamber again next year.
The Associated Press contributed.

Senate Democratic leadership laid out Tuesday a drafted bill to add protections for gay and transgender Hoosiers in state civil rights law.

Senate Minority Leader Tim Lanane, D-Anderson, said he intended to sponsor the proposal, which would prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity in the areas of employment, housing and public accommodations.

The proposed legislation retains existing exemptions for small businesses with fewer than six employees and religious organizations, such as churches or parochial schools. It also adds veteran status as a protected class.

“Hoosiers expect nothing less than equal protection under the law for LGBT Hoosiers and that’s what we’ve drafted,” Lanane said in a statement. “While others are keeping conversations behind closed doors, we’re ready to move this forward.”

While Democrats pledged to address gay and transgender rights after the backlash following passage of Indiana's Religious Freedom Restoration Act earlier this year, it remains to be seen where Republicans — who hold a supermajority in the Statehouse — stand on the issue.

In response to the Senate Democrats' proposal, Senate President Pro Tem David Long, R-Fort Wayne, said, “I appreciate Sen. Lanane’s input on this issue, and I look forward to reviewing his proposed legislation. I expect the Senate Republican caucus to have our own contributions to this discussion in the days ahead as we all seek to find the right solution for our state.”
Several Indiana cities and towns have implemented their own anti-discrimination laws. Most recently, Carmel passed one Monday after weeks of contentious debate.

Some, particularly social conservatives, oppose the expansion of civil rights to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Hoosiers, because they say it would infringe upon their religious liberty and ability to live by their faiths.
