Hillary Clinton's dominant performance in the Democrats' first presidential debate a month ago sealed her front-runner status, leaving politics watchers with one chief question ahead of Saturday's match-up: Will she slip?

Clinton's backers say that's not likely. The former secretary of state and runner-up for the 2008 Democratic nomination has already navigated through 24 nationally televised debates, last month's 11-hour congressional hearing on Benghazi and numerous live-camera encounters, like the recent one with an Iowan who wanted to know what she’d do to impress his dog.

Her supporters instead argue that the interrogation lamp will be hotter for Bernie Sanders — with the scrutiny focused on whether he'll stay true to the positive-campaigning pledge that he takes so much pride in.
And just about everyone agrees that the stakes are also high for former Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley, whose wispy poll numbers threaten to waft his struggling campaign into nothingness.

When the three candidates take the stage at the CBS News/KCCI/Des Moines Register event Saturday night at Drake University, they will be trying to bag undecided voters, including the draft-Joe Biden hopefuls who are still in the grief process over his decision not to run for president.

“I’m going to listen to it and see if it will get me off the sidelines,” said state Rep. Jim Lykam, a Davenport Democrat who was the first legislator to endorse Biden during the 2008 presidential race.
Follow Iowa Caucus news, photos, videos with Iowa Caucuses App: iPhone or iPad | Android

All three 2016 Democratic presidential contenders have been prepared for debate questions by various “Wow, I didn’t see that coming” moments on the campaign trail, like when an Iowa City man stood up in Clinton’s Coralville audience Nov. 3 to introduce his dog, “a first-time voter” who he said is trying to “figure out who it is she’s going to caucus for.”
Clinton rolled with it.
“Now, what are her issues?” Clinton said.
“There are rabbits that keep coming into our yard,” the Iowan answered, “but our landlord won’t secure the border.”
MORE:

Iowans cast the first presidential votes in the nation on Feb. 1. Earlier this week, Republican U.S. Sen. Chuck Grassley offered some general election food for thought for Democrats who might feel insecure about caucusing for Clinton.

“It ought to be based on the proposition like the Bush name — is the Clinton name too much for people to absorb for a continuation of a Clinton presidency?” he said. “And to the extent to which she says she approves of the Obama administration and wants to go further ... is the country ready to go further?”

The debate, broadcast on CBS, begins at 8 p.m. Watching from inside Sheslow Auditorium will be about 700 invited guests who received free tickets. The crowd will be mostly party activists and donors, VIPs invited by debate sponsors and a smattering of Drake students and faculty.
Here are seven topics to look out for, based on interviews with party insiders and politics watchers.

Has Sanders left an indelible impression that it’s taboo for Democrats to attack Clinton on the email controversy? Or will the Vermont U.S. senator try to argue that the email distraction, and therefore Clinton, hurts the progressive agenda?

Sanders’ outburst in the Las Vegas debate — “I think the American people are sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails” — was interpreted as validating Clinton's own dismissal of the topic, partly because she immediately put that spin on Sanders' remark by giving him a big smile and a handshake.

“Sanders may have boxed himself into a corner, in the short term, given the buzz-worthy clip from the first debate. As such, it is more likely Sanders makes veiled references to ‘trustworthiness’ and ‘honesty,’” said Eric Ostermeier, a political analyst at the University of Minnesota’s Humphrey School of Public Affairs.

But lately, Sanders has been trying to recast his words, possibly to reflect his intended meaning — that the FBI investigation is important, and that Clinton may be more of a controversy magnet than the standard-bearer for “the real issues facing America.”
Also visit: DesMoinesRegister.com/IowaCaucuses | Candidate tracker and calendar in Iowa | Sign up for Caucuses Newsletter

As secretary of state, Clinton routed her email traffic through her own home-based private server rather than a government server. The FBI is investigating whether that put any confidential information at risk from hackers.
Sanders said in an interview with CNN immediately after the debate that there’s an appropriate process in place for Clinton's “email situation.”
“Let it play itself out,” he said Oct. 14.
But he told the Wall Street Journal in an interview on Nov. 4: “I did not say, 'End the investigation.’ That's silly."

When underdog Barack Obama engaged in a slugfest with Clinton in the 2008 race, he threw stink bombs at her for her past role as a corporate lawyer sitting on the board of Walmart, for being the “default” nominee and the “brand name” in Democratic insider politics.
Will Clinton’s 2016 rivals unleash their daggers?

Possible lines of attack in addition to her unknown culpability in the active FBI investigation of her email system: potential conflicts of interest from foreign donations flowing into the Clinton Foundation during her tenure at Foggy Bottom; the big speaking fees she took from public universities and Wall Street; her comment that she’s “dead broke” despite having a net worth of more than $15 million; and her policy flip-flops.

“Clinton’s foreign policy hawkishness, the open wound of her support of the war in Iraq, remain available for Sanders, with proven purity on those fronts, to expose in Iowa,” said Douglas Burns, a longtime Iowa politics watcher and columnist for the Carroll Daily Times Herald, which he owns.

More pointed debate on immigration is likely, too, given that Clinton has caught attention for saying in New Hampshire on Monday that she voted numerous times to “build a barrier” to keep “illegal immigrants” from coming into the country.
Can Sanders break out without attacking, or without getting attacked for attacking? All eyes will be on whether he can strike a balance, Democrats said.

Since Sanders went hard after Clinton at the Jefferson Jackson dinner in Des Moines, Team Clinton has sought to portray Sanders as crossing the line from offering comparisons on issues to mudslinging.
Sanders told the Register in April, shortly after he declared his candidacy, that he's an honest, scandal-free politician who rejects sleazy campaign tactics.

“I do not believe in these terrible personal attacks on people. Nobody I know is perfect. No one I know has never done anything wrong in their lives,” he said, noting he has never run a negative advertisement.

But Team Clinton went after Sanders last week for saying that consistency on issues “does speak to the character of a person.” Sanders was answering a question from the Wall Street Journal about Clinton's policy reversals. Clinton spokesman Josh Schwerin fired back: “It's disappointing Senator Sanders and his campaign strategists have chosen to change direction and engage in the type of personal attacks that they previously said he wouldn't do.”

“I think there is a difference between mudslinging and issue contrasts,” said Iowa Democratic operative Jeff Link of LinkStrategies in Des Moines. “However, Sanders emerged by doing neither. Instead, he touched a nerve among Democrats by talking about his own positions and ideas for the future. I’m not sure why you would abandon a strategy that grew your base from nothing to about 40 percent.”
Sanders has said he feels baited.
"I can't walk down a hallway in the nation's capital without people begging me to beat up on Hillary Clinton, attack Hillary Clinton," he said Nov. 6 at MSNBC's "First in the South" forum.
O’Malley’s fresh-faced earnestness has turned into urgent determination as he goes on the offense — after both Clinton and Sanders.
“Desperate candidates — like desperate people — are always the most intriguing to watch," Burns said.
Democratic insiders said they don’t see O'Malley emerging as Clinton’s running mate, so he need not show deference with that in mind.
“I think he has to hit Clinton. Go after the queen, so to speak,” Burns said.

The best hope for O'Malley might be for Clinton and Sanders to attack each other, said Des Moines Democratic strategist Grant Woodard. "People may be turned off by both and go to him by default, similar to the 'mutually assured destruction' that took down both Richard Gephardt and Howard Dean in favor of John Kerry and John Edwards in 2004,” he said.

Gephardt had the lead at this point in the 2004 Iowa caucuses (27 percent), followed by Dean (20 percent), but Kerry (15 percent) and Edwards (5 percent) climbed to more than 30 percent each on caucus day.
Clinton won’t try to stomp Sanders because she won't want to alienate his supporters, politics watchers said. She's keenly attuned to the need for party unity once the nomination is won.

“Whatever you care about,” Clinton said in Grinnell on her most recent Iowa trip, “whatever you clap for, whatever you think is important will be at stake in this election. And it is really important that the Democrats win. There is no doubt in my mind that there is no such thing as a perfect candidate, because there is no such thing as a perfect person.”
Link said: “She has been making gains by talking about equal pay and exposing the House Republicans for their political motives in the committee hearing. I think she will continue that path.”

By opposing the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, the three Democrats are viewed in some quarters as placing their fealty to labor union members over the interests of farmers. That hands Republicans a big issue to use in Iowa in the general election, Burns said.
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, a popular former Iowa governor, has declared that the trade pact would be a boon for Iowa-grown grain and pork, Burns noted.

After the text of the proposed deal was released on Nov. 5, Vilsack sent out a glowing news release saying this "high-standard agreement" would mean great opportunity for the ag industry and "higher-paying American jobs."
"What can the Democratic presidential hopefuls say? 'We're right on TPP, and Tom Vilsack, who is from Iowa and has led United States ag policy for the better part of a decade, is wrong?'" Burns said.
It's a trendy strategy for candidates to localize their campaign-trail answers.
Clinton, in particular, has tried to show her mastery on Iowa-specific issues, name-dropping local people, places and current events.
When: 8 p.m., Saturday; 9 p.m. central
Main host: CBS News
Partners: CBS affiliate KCCI-TV, The Des Moines Register, Twitter, Drake University, the Iowa Democratic Party and the Democratic National Committee
Debate site: Sheslow Auditorium, Drake University

Moderators: Lead moderator is John Dickerson of CBS News, anchor of “Face the Nation.” Also moderating are Nancy Cordes, congressional correspondent, CBS News; Kevin Cooney, anchor, KCCI-TV; and Kathie Obradovich, columnist, The Des Moines Register.
Tickets: The Iowa Democratic Party has a very limited number of free tickets available; those interested in attending should email info@iowademocrats.org.
